job_title: Associate Sales Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: They hire a ton of college graduates, a strategy shared by all smart companies in my opinion. As such, it means they're willing to teach and train, and the investment they make in employees is much appreciated. I learned a lot about technologies that had previously been foreign: database, middleware, infrastructure, on-premises, and cloud solutions. Plus, it also pays well for people who lack experience. Never found it to be a particularly demanding job, and I very very rarely took home work after leaving.
cons: The other side of hiring young is that many managers are young and often unqualified. They don't seek out input from those who are managed, so if you get a poor manager it means you're likely stuck with them, and their word will hold more weight than yours. Being tied to sales means you're also tied to quotas and other unimportant metrics, many of which are typically outside of your control.

job_title: Senior Project/Program Manager in Omaha, NE
pros: Flexible in that you can work from home, "unlimited vacation" if your manager let's you take it, and decent benefits.
cons: There are a lot of cons, but the primary offense is the systemic misogyny and racism that constantly are identified and ignored. Women are paid far less and tasked with far more. Men are given promotions for doing much less. They refuse to actually do a salary comparison because they know the results will be bad and could implicate them in various lawsuits that are ongoing. A few final notes: bad actors are not punished but rather promoted, pay increases almost never occur, management is tone deaf, and the reward for good work is a lot more work.

review_title: Not a Good Experience in Tech Support
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Good health care benefits.
Coworkers were very smart and professional.
cons:
I worked at Oracle for over 5 years and never saw a pay raise. 
Technical Support Management only cared about their metrics. My first manager was good and seemed to care about his team somewhat. My second manager could hardly remember the names of his team members and constantly pointed out mistakes and flaws, very rarely praising a job well done.
Formal training was nonexistent. Employees were required to read manuals and documents on their own for their training.
We were significantly under staffed and over worked, yet they still laid off one third of our team (twice).
Senior management would consistently preach about good customer service, then they would take away all of the tools to provide said service.
Stressful environment. I don't miss it for minute!

review_title: Corporate Politics, Internal Competition, Little Support from Managment
pros: Class of training is extremely thorough and provides good sales foundation. Great way to build professional network. Immediate experience interacting with key executives at customer accounts. Looks good on a resume and provides professional experience.
cons:
Company is structured so there are minimum 10 Oracle reps mapped to the same account, causing a lot of internal competition and conflicting incentives - this ultimately causes a lot of frustration for customers and rarely puts customer interests first. 

Most sales reps have large egos, making collaboration difficult even if you try. Oracle puts a lot of pressure on sales to meet challenging quotas/kpis, so everyone is so busy if you ask for help you're very aware of taking away people's "precious and valuable time". Company culture is similar to 'bro culture' in a college fraternity.

Management asks a lot of their teams in terms of activity, pipeline, closed deals, and additional trainings/projects, but are so overwhelmed themselves they offer reps virtually no support when help is needed. Activity expectations are unrealistic, focusing only on calls when reps have communicated countless times that emails and linkedin are significantly more successful mediums. 

Also, career development is challenging, with managers often keeping employees in roles for a minimum of 12-18 months and discourage employees from networking/exploring next roles before then. No HR support either - in the internal system under 'my designated HR rep' only information is a 1-800 HR support line.

review_title: not customer and employee centric company
pros:
Big organisation with big budgets, can sponsor whatever makes employees "happy" such as fancy events, kitchen equipment, games, teambuildings.

As a designer, you have plenty of space to experiment. The UIs are really bad, it is easy to make them better. Good for juniours who need to screw up few things first.

You will get a top end equipment such as latest model of macbook, all perriferies you need.
cons:
Culture is terrible. Typical corporate culture even though they try to look like cool team. It is not truth. Problems are fixed with free lunch and then the leaders brag about it for weeks.

There is not enough designers, expect overload of work. 

More then designing you will be business modeling.

Designers are generally not considered on the same level as PMs or DEVs. You will need to build your own position. Not easy for juniors. There is a lot of pushbacks.

Research is not the standard. If you want it, you do it. Do not expect PMs to base their decisions on research. They use gut feeling or middle management advice they do not completely understand.

Middle management is not helpful, they ale a blocker from being fast and agile team. They block things from release because they want things to be 100% ready. They do not like to risk anything.

review_title: Great place and stability but depends on the area.
pros:
- The DB org is top-noch, so it is the preferred place to be.
- It is both a pro and con: great friends/peers but a few ego-maniacs too.
- Managers are usually technical, which is great.
- In many teams you can achieve good work-life balance.
- Continuous education funding (they sponsored my Msc!)
- Great stability in your job (is normal to count your time in decades here).
- A lot of diversity in the business units, if you want a change usually you can find it within the company; which is a self-contained universe.
cons:
- Outside of DB org, things vary more and can be less stable.
- Some areas use legacy processes and technology.
- Some areas compete to each other rather than collaborating (same with some peers).
- Depending on the area, you may get stuck with old technology or niche knowledge for many years.
- In some projects, you may have too many meetings with big audiences; which is usually not very productive.

review_title: Finally taking UX moves; a lot of tech debts though
pros: WLB; Nice teammates and management; lots of new things happening to UX; designers have the rights to say (not in OCI; OCI have their own designers' org)
cons: Less competitive TC comparing with other same-scale companies (yep, dry promo and almost no yearly bonus). It's not long since Oracle started to hire UX designers and integrate UX into product development, so there are definitely a lot of legacy features are framed in the outdated design system that need to be redesigned. This becomes obvious when they try to switch to a new design system (Redwood). Clearly UX is still understaffed and needs more budget to attract better designers (to come or stay).

review_title: Unless you're desperate for a job, stay away.
pros:
Initially, I thought pay. They managed to screw that up. 
401k & health Benefits were very good.
cons: In my experience this was the  most Dysfunctional company I've ever worked for. Constant internal fighting for deals and stealing of deals. Other internal teams actively blocking you in accounts. Can't get commission checks right, and forget about base pay raises. Most customers hated Oracle. Typically because they felt they were cheated or abused by Oracle at some point. In my experience, their anger was usually justified. People/recruiters often commented they were surprised how long I'd stayed at Oracle as they have such a bad reputation in the industry.  I recommend you look elsewhere for employment, and only consider Oracle as a last resort.

job_title: Business Operations Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
If you find yourself in the "Right" organization within the company, there are many benefits. If you don't, your experience may be vastly different. In some organizations:
- More stable parts of the organization provide a feeling of job security - its common for people to leave and come back a few months/years later
- Lots of opportunity for working across teams and getting exposure to different areas
- Unlimited vacation (not applicable to all orgs and not all countries)
cons:
- It seems that the company is constantly reorganizing, so if you find yourself in a less stable part of the organization, expect to have a new role and new management chain at least every year, if not even more often.
- If you are fortunate enough to be in a more stable part of the company, there is much more security but little room for upward growth and development
- The typical red tape exists, as expected at any mega company of this size

review_title: Oracle – The company which values a laptop more than the life of an employee during the corona virus pandemic
pros: How can Oracle have any pros when it puts an employee at a health risk during the coronavirus pandemic. Shame on you Oracle.
cons:
Firstly, let me say – The HR folks at Oracle have no control of their duties and the VP (My manager) considers himself above all company policies, compliance acts, rules, and regulations. The HR folks are mere puppets who tolerate the whims and fancies of the VP. HR keeps a blind eye as they have no control at all. The VP intervenes in tasks that do not concern his duties and HR allows the VP to do whatever the VP wants. (The VP referred here is my manager) 

Corona Virus pandemic hit us unexpectedly and my wife delivered our first baby when the virus was spreading rapidly. So, we were even more cautious and didn’t step out of the house unless and until it was an emergency ensuring the safety of our newborn child, avoided all travel, and didn’t allow anyone to enter our house in Bangalore. 

I accepted another job offer during the pandemic and I put down my papers by informing my manager who sits at a VP level as mentioned earlier. After I put down my papers, I was told by my manager to coordinate with Mr. X to do the company asset (Laptop and accessories) handover formalities on my last day. I did the same and the company asset handover was finalized with Mr. X to be done at the nearest Oracle premises near my house. I was happy that I had confirmed and finalized the asset submission at the Oracle office which was close to my residence considering the coronavirus situation that was creating havoc in Bangalore and is still creating havoc.

On my second last day at Oracle, my manager informs me that I must submit the company assets to the Oracle office which is very far from my residence, and the reason he states is that he prefers to have all assets in one place. This is even after I had confirmed the asset submission to the Oracle office that was close to my residence and even after I had requested to allow me to submit the company assets to the Oracle office close to my residence due to the corona situation in Bangalore. See the sadist behavior of my manager – He first informs me when I put down my papers to coordinate with X and do the asset handover formalities and on the second last day he intervenes and says to submit to the Oracle office that is far from my residence. The HR folks were just mere spectators, but they didn’t even bother to intervene. 

Every company across the globe is putting its best foot forward to ensure the safety of its employees as its core priority. But Oracle ensured that I am harassed and tortured mentally during the pandemic time. I wonder how such companies and managers can put someone’s life at a risk. Not only that, but my manager also wanted me to go out and exchange my laptop charger with another team member and wanted me to submit my team member's broken charger on my last working day to Oracle. I refused to exchange as I wanted to avoid meeting anyone during the pandemic and, I didn’t want to do any fraudulent activity by submitting a broken company asset back to the company. 

I was mentally harassed and tortured by this incident and I raised the harassment complaint to the top officials including the CEO. I hope the reality of the Corona Virus situation sinks into them and hopefully they realize how difficult it is to face such harassment from sadist managers and incompetent HR folks. 

The HR person who contacted me didn’t even have the courtesy to apologize for what happened and was arrogant when talking to me on such a serious sensitive issue. Instead of focusing on the harassment issue that I raised, they were interested in knowing whether I have a “PROBLEM” with my manager. See how sad their mentality is and how they are handling the harassment issue that I raised. 

I am glad that I resigned from this toxic company which put me and my family at a health risk during this corona virus pandemic. Shame on you Oracle.

However, since there is such favoritism going on, opportunities are limited based on your connection with the leadership and not based on value you will bring or ability to do the job at hand. I’ve seen very qualified employees interview internally for promotions and not get the job because a manager has favorites. If you’re not a favorite, you won’t grow here.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: The expenses you can charge to your AMEX card. Expensive 5 stars dinners, open bar drinks, travels, shopping, and so much more!
cons:
The culture has declined over time but always been problematic. Oracle is not the type of place that rewards identifying risks and problems. There is a huge emphasis on following the party line and never questioning decisions or paths forward. Top performers are labeled as a troublemaker when they try and warn the organization of customer problems or potential issues with product or approach. And eventually they get let go. It's become like a mafia since new management came from AWS, Microsoft, and Salesforce. 

You either drink the coolaid and shut up, or you can spend your entire career here watching the "yes man" types get ahead.

cons: Some corporate procedures are surprisingly complicated and long.

review_title: Absolutely no mobility, top-down exploitative company
pros: The benefits are decent and it was reliable work from home income during the pandemic.
cons: The role itself is designed to deal with the repercussions of technologically illiterate construction workers being forced to use an Oracle SaaS with a steep learning curve. The expectation is to keep mindlessly answering calls and thanklessly letting customers berate you with their frustrations with the service. Resources are rarely available and questions often get delayed, if any, response from peers. Management generally engages with the team with a positive attitude but gossips amongst themselves. Some managers prefer to find minutiae to penalize reps for instead of addressing larger issues that effect the entire team's workflow and morale. Promotions and raises as a whole are a facade as positions are almost always filled with outside hires. I've worked for several years and taken on several additional responsibilities than my initial job description with no increase in compensation, hoping all of it would amount to upward mobility. Even with glowing recommendations from some managers, team members, and coworkers from peripheral departments, my applications have been fruitless, usually without even a response of interest. After addressing these concerns with management, I was told to wait for more senior reps to have their chance, and to keep thanklessly picking up additional tasks and responsibilities.
